security_audit.summary: Pure documentation and template skill containing Python code examples for matplotlib visualization. No network calls, no file system access beyond output, no credential handling, and no external command execution. Safe for installation.

content.value_statement: Creating publication-quality visualizations in Python requires understanding matplotlib API, styling options, and best practices. This skill provides templates, code examples, and troubleshooting guidance for generating professional plots, charts, and 3D visualizations for research and data analysis.
actual_capabilities: Create line plots, scatter plots, bar charts, and histograms
Generate heatmaps, contour plots, and 3D visualizations
Apply custom styling, colormaps, and themes
Export figures to PNG, PDF, SVG formats
limitations: Requires matplotlib package installed in Python environment
Does not generate animated plots or interactive dashboards
Cannot directly read data files (requires pandas or numpy)

prompt_templates.title: Basic plot
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a line plot showing x and y data with matplotlib. Include axis labels, title, and grid lines.

prompt_templates.title: Statistical chart
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a histogram and box plot to show the distribution of data values. Add a normal distribution overlay.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-panel figure
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a figure with multiple subplots showing different views of the same data.

prompt_templates.title: Styled visualization
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a plot with publication-quality styling using constrained layout, proper font sizes, and colorblind-friendly colors.

output_examples.input: Create a scatter plot showing the relationship between two variables with color coding
output: Use ax.scatter() with c parameter for color mapping
Add a colorbar with plt.colorbar() to show the legend
Set appropriate markersize and alpha for visibility
Include axis labels and a title describing the relationship

best_practices: Use the object-oriented interface (fig, ax = plt.subplots()) instead of pyplot for complex figures
Set figure size and DPI at creation time rather than resizing afterward
Apply constrained_layout=True or tight_layout() to prevent label overlap
Use colorblind-friendly colormaps like viridis for accessibility
anti_patterns: Avoid relying on the pyplot state machine for multi-figure workflows
Do not use the jet colormap due to perceptual non-uniformity
Avoid hardcoding magic numbers for styling; use rcParams for consistency
Do not forget to close figures with plt.close() when creating many plots

faq.question: Which Python versions support matplotlib?
faq.answer: Matplotlib supports Python 3.9 and newer. Check requirements.txt for exact version compatibility.

faq.question: What are the file size limits for exported figures?
faq.answer: File size depends on DPI and content complexity. For web use 150 DPI, for print use 300 DPI.

faq.question: How do I integrate with pandas DataFrames?
faq.answer: DataFrame.plot() methods use matplotlib internally. Pass ax=df.plot() to customize further.

faq.question: Is my data safe when creating plots?
faq.answer: Yes. Matplotlib processes data locally in memory only. No data is sent to external servers.

faq.question: Why do my labels overlap?
faq.answer: Use constrained_layout=True or tight_layout(). For long labels, rotate tick labels with rotation=45.

faq.question: How does this compare to seaborn or plotly?
faq.answer: Matplotlib provides low-level control. Seaborn offers high-level statistical plots. Plotly creates interactive web visualizations.
